docs.lead_paragraph: THE birth of Jeremy Tacchetti-Carelli was celebrated more like a family reunion than a medical procedure. Not only was Silvana Tacchetti-Carelli's husband, Marcio Carelli, present to comfort and coach her during the three-hour delivery last month; the whole family was watching. Her mother, Vittoria Tacchetti; her brother, Aldo; even her 4-year-old son, Fransisco.
docs.abstract: Movement to involve fathers in childbirth is evolving to include entire family, friends and even co-workers in ritual; demand has led most hospitals to add 'birthing rooms' that can accomodate gatherings, although most such births take place at home or at growing number of birthing centers; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Following is last night's debate in San Diego between President Clinton and Bob Dole, as transcribed by the Federal Document Clearing House, a private transcription service. The moderator was Jim Lehrer of PBS and questions were asked by San Diego area voters selected by the Gallup polling organization. MODERATOR The order for this evening was set by coin toss. We begin now with Senator Dole and his opening statement. Senator Dole. DOLE Thank you very much, Jim.

headline.main: Transcript of Second Televised Debate Between Clinton and Dole

docs.abstract: Transcript of second televised debate between President Clinton and Bob Dole; photo (L)
docs.snippet: Following is last night's debate in San Diego between President Clinton and Bob Dole, as transcribed by the Federal Document Clearing House, a private transcription service. The moderator was Jim Lehrer of PBS and questions were asked by San Diego...

docs.lead_paragraph: IT is a love affair that begins at birth: the human and the microbe. The human fetus, before birth, is both innocent and germ-free. Skin, mouth and gut are all sterile. But it is a dirty world, and the adjustment to it starts as the newborn passes through the birth canal, or in a Caesarean delivery the second it is touched by a doctor or midwife.

headline.main: From Birth, Body Houses Microbe Zoo

docs.abstract: Sandra Blakeslee describes how bacteria come to live in and on infant from moment of birth; in first few months of life, infant is colonized by successive invasions of microbes; Dr Jeffrey Gordon, microbiologist, notes that at least 400 species of bacteria begin to set up housekeeping in baby's gut and many more reside on skin, mouth and elsewhere; only a few bacteria out of thousands of known species are virulent threats to human health and welfare; ones that colonize human bodies are, for most part, working on their hosts' behalf; photos of some common bacteria that inhabit healthy human body; drawing (L)
